title: Customization of {distill} website
contents:
Theme
The RStudio website has a Distill for R Markdown article that I referred to often when I was creating my website. I had no clue when I started creating this website and I really wanted it to personalize it to my liking. I started with the Theming section. I used the create_theme() function to create my personalized theme, called “courtney_theme.css”.
Coloring
It took me a long time to figure out what format the colors were in. I finally found that they are hex colors. Black is #000000, white is #FFFFFF, ad every other color is somewhere in between. I used a Hex to RGB Color Converter to get to the colors that I wanted for the background, headers, mouse hover, and font colors.

This is the color scheme I was going for.
Font
Changing fonts on the website did not end up being too tricky. I also found instructions on how to change the default font on the Distill for R Markdown article. First, I went to the Google Fonts website. Then I searched for the ones that I liked. I chose three fonts that I thought looked nice together and imported them into my courtney_theme.css and then inserted them into my code where I wanted them.

title: Building a website using R {distill}
contents: This Youtube video by Lisa Lendway was really helpful in creating my distill website. Lisa is a professor at Macalester College and an RStudio instructor. This tutorial was from A to Z how to create a beautiful {distill} website. It was inspiring to also see her struggling through R and learning from her mistakes throughout the video. It made me feel better when I was also struggling through creating and customizing my own website. Her finished website from this video looked really cool, so make sure to check that out too.

title: Sharing on Short Notice: How to Get Your Teaching Materials Online with R Markdown
contents:
This is a seminar by Alison Hill and Desiree De Leon on how to share R Markdown files and Distill websites online using the drag-and-drop function on Netlify. I used Netlify to make my website public. It gave me a random, funny URL, but it only costs about $15/year to create a custom URL. Maybe when I have an actual job, I will do that so my URL isn’t www.frosty-beaver-3fd4d5.netlify.app (no joke).

Netlify makes it easy to create a unique URL for R Markdowns and Distill websites.
This video was very descriptive and helped me a lot with understanding how to make my distill website live for others to view. I was mostly interested in {rmarkdown} and {pagedown}, but they also talk about {bookdown} and {blogdown} if you are interested. This seminar was aimed at educators to help them make more reproducible material for their students, but it was very helpful for my project too!
